results.title: Kittens are born
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Johnston, Hugh Johnston and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Follows a female cat from pregnancy through labour and the birth of three kittens. Emphasises the birth process and parental care immediately following birth. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Kites: a collage of kites and kite flyers
results.creator_credit: Simon Heaven, Peter R. Jones, Arts Council of Great Britain and Compass Films (UK)
results.brief_description: Shows kites soaring above city heights, wafting across scenic countryside and displaying an array of designs, shapes and multi-tiered constructions. Explores kite mechanics, traditional patterns and characteristics and scientific and other practical applications of these fanciful toys. Includes live footage of kite experiments and archival stills of similarly innovative attempts of the past.

results.title: Kite flying
results.creator_credit: David Waddington, Australia Council and David Waddington Productions
results.brief_description: Peter Travis sees kite-making as an art form and himself as a sculptor. The complex strings of geometric pieces that he assembles to form his large kites, he calls “flying colourfield geometric constructions”. Travis is shown flying his kites and talking about their making. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Kitchen sink
results.creator_credit: Alison MacLean, Bridget Ikin and Hibiscus Films
results.brief_description: Alison MacLean’s highly acclaimed first film, shot in stark black-and-white, is a wordless experimental horror/romance short about a women who gets much more than she bargains for when she dislodges a rope of hair from the bowels of her kitchen sink. A darkly humorous, tender and disturbing love story about abject female desire that evokes elements of the Frankenstein story. The film competed at Cannes in 1989 and won eight international awards.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alison MacLean, Bridget Ikin and Hibiscus Films

results.title: Kitchen come true
results.creator_credit: Ernest Reid, Alvin Armstrong, Betty Brunke and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how an old fashioned farm kitchen may be updated into a modern and convenient 1945 kitchen through careful planning and efficient conversion of existing space and materials. During the planning stage, the following are considered: saving steps in the kitchen; provision of adequate shelf space; facilitating house cleaning; provision of ample laundry space; washing and cleaning area; and a well-lit desk for children’s homework. Shows the planning, design, construction and enjoyment of a new kitchen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ernest Reid, Alvin Armstrong, Betty Brunke and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Kitchen and Canteen Safety
results.brief_description: Few other work areas match the kitchen in number and variation of risks and hazards. Hygiene, personal protective equipment, manual handling, use of knives, slips, trips and falls, dealing with kitchen fires and general hazards are all addressed and appropriate action suggested in this program.

results.title: Kitchen = Wo ai chu fang
results.creator_credit: Yim Ho, Akira Morishige, Harvest Crown and Pineast Pictures
results.brief_description: Banana Yoshimoto’s popular Japanese novel ‘Kitchen’ is radically reworked in this film of the same name by director Yim-Ho. ‘Kitchen’ is a slowly paced but affectionate study on grief and the emotional state and journey of the bereaved. When Aggie’s grandmother (Yasuko Tomita), her last living relative, dies, she is taken in by hairdresser acquaintance Louie (Jordan Chan), and Emma (Law Kar Ying) his transsexual ‘mother’. With warmth and affection the two slowly arouse Aggie from her listless state and nurture her back to life. ‘Kitchen’ uses food as a constant metaphor throughout the film to explore emotional states and to symbolise the depth of unexplored feelings. When tragedy strikes again with sickly premonition, both Louie and Aggie are forced to revisit their grief, triggering unresolved issues. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: Kita: or, What have you done for me lately?
results.creator_credit: William C. Jersey, Richard L. Wormser and BNA Films
results.brief_description: Frederick Herzberg points out that improvements in hygiene, wages, working conditions, and fringe benefits do not have a lasting effect on job motivation, and that the work people do is more important than how they are treated.
